content.description: Substance <math alttext="delta H naught sub f, in kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <msubsup> <mrow> <mi>H</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>∘</mo> </mrow> </msubsup> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>(kJ/mol)</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> <math alttext="C H 4 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="negative 75" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>75</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 0 <math alttext="C O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="negative 390" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>390</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H 2 O gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="negative 240" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>240</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> Natural gas consists primarily of <math alttext="C H 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is combusted according to the following chemical equation.
content.question: <math alttext="C H 4 gas plus 2 O 2 gas react to produce C O 2 gas plus 2 H 2 O gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Based on the standard enthalpies of formation in the table above, which of the following expressions give the approximate enthalpy change for the reaction <math alttext="delta H naught, sub r x n" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <msubsup> <mrow> <mi>H</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>∘</mi> </mrow> </msubsup> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="delta H naught, sub r x n equals, open parenthesis, negative 75 kilojoules per mole, close parenthesis, minus, open bracket, open parenthesis, negative 390 kilojoules per mole, close parenthesis, plus 2 times, open parenthesis, negative 240 kilojoules per mole, close parenthesis, close bracket" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <msubsup> <mrow> <mi>H</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>∘</mi> </mrow> </msubsup> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>75</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>kJ/mol</mtext> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mrow> <mo>[</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>390</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"> </mspace> <mtext>kJ/mol</mtext> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>+</mo> <mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>240</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"> </mspace> <mtext>kJ/mol</mtext> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>]</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
